title-group.subtitle: Are intellectually disabled patients given enough information to consent to medical treatment?

contrib.aff: Greater Manchester West NHS Foundation Trust, UK
Greater Manchester West NHS Foundation Trust, UK

author-notes.corresp: Nathan T.M. Huneke, School of Medicine, University of Manchester, UK Email: Nathan.huneke@nhs.net

abstract.p: Patients with learning disabilities are not always involved in decision-making about their medications. This may mean that some patients are unfairly denied of their autonomy. We carried out an audit of current practice concerning consent to treatment in patients with learning disabilities against best practice guidelines. Data were collected via a questionnaire given to a sample of 70 patients with learning disabilities within the Salford catchment area. This questionnaire assessed whether patients were involved in decision-making regarding their medications and whether they were being given enough information to give informed consent. A total of 45 patients completed questionnaires. Overall, the patients’ knowledge of their medications was poor, particularly of the proposed duration, possible disadvantages and name of the treatment. It appears that doctors are engaging these patients during consultations and discussing their medications. However, the delivery of this information needs to be improved, and patients’ understanding and recall need to be checked more thoroughly.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A person is deemed as having the capacity to make a decision for themselves if they are able to understand the information relevant to the decision, retain this information for long enough to make the decision and then communicate this decision (Mental Capacity Act, 2005). Information relevant to the initiation of new medications includes awareness of the drug name, its purpose, the administration schedule, possible adverse effects and any other special administration instructions (Ascione et al., 1986; Storm et al., 2009).

It is unethical to administer medications to patients without their consent if they have the capacity to make healthcare decisions, and doing so breaks the principle of patient autonomy and constitutes assault (Wong et al., 2005). Previous studies have shown that patients with mild-to-moderate learning disabilities might have the capacity to make simple decisions about their health (Arscott et al., 2000; Goldsmith et al., 2008). Despite this, many of these patients are not involved in the decisions about their care and appear to lack knowledge about the medication they are taking (Arscott et al., 2000; Heslop et al., 2005; Goldsmith et al., 2008; Keywood and Flynn, 2003)

We carried out an audit to determine whether patients with learning disabilities are receiving the information they require, in a form that they can understand, to make informed decisions about their medication.

sec.title: Aims of the audit
sec.p: The objectives of this audit are to evaluate current practice concerning consent to treatment in patients with learning disabilities against best practice guidelines and to ascertain whether patients with learning disabilities are given enough information, in a form that they can understand, to make informed decisions about their medication.

sec.title: Standards
sec.p: The present audit was designed to test the following standards, which were obtained following a review of several sources (Department of Health, 2001; General Medical Council, 2008; Mental Capacity Act, 2005; Mental Welfare Commission for Scotland, 2010; Nursing and Midwifery Council, 2007; The British Psychological Society, 2006; The Royal College of Psychiatrists, 2004). If the patient is found to have the capacity to consent:

list-item.p: the patient must be involved with decisions about their health,

the patient must be provided information, in a form they can understand, on the following:
the benefits of the proposed treatment,
the risks of the proposed treatment,
what the treatment will involve,
the implications of not having the treatment, and
the practical effects on their lives of having and not having the treatment,
the patient's understanding of the information provided must always be checked,
the decision of the person must be made voluntarily,
an assessment of capacity should be recorded in the person’s notes or, where appropriate, in a form for adults who are unable to consent.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The audit was conducted in Salford (Greater Manchester, UK). A total of 215 adult patients with intellectual disabilities, who were currently living in supported accommodation were identified. Of these patients, 87 lived in supported tenancies, while 128 patients lived in private care homes. We selected every third patient living in each type of accommodation until we had achieved a sample of 35 patients living in supported tenancies and 35 patients living in privately funded homes, making a total of 70 patients.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: Data were collected via a questionnaire designed for patients with learning disabilities to complete. Patients were sent a covering letter and questionnaire to their home address by post. Both the covering letter and the questionnaire were written in an easy-read format and included Picture Communication Symbols (PCS) to allow the questionnaire to be accessible for patients with intellectual disabilities. The PCS were created in conjunction with the Total Communications Lead from the Salford City Council Learning Difficulties Partnership Board. The covering letter explained the purpose of the audit, why it was important and stressed that all information gathered would remain confidential. Those who agreed to take part were asked to complete and return the questionnaire with the help of their support worker. The questions assessed the patients’ knowledge regarding the following eight items:

list-item.p: consequences of not taking the medication, and
foods or drinks that are contraindicated.

sec.p: These items were assessed for each medication the patient was taking. The answers to these questions were examined for accuracy using the 61st edition of the British National Formulary (British Medical Association and Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain, 2011). Answers that were incorrect or recorded as ‘don’t know’ were given a score of zero. All correct information was given a score of one. Next, the patients’ knowledge regarding their medications for each question was calculated as a ratio of the number of points scored to the number of medications they were currently taking. This allowed comparisons of knowledge between patients, despite varying numbers of medications (Barat et al., 2001). Based on previous publications, a cut off of 50% was decided upon as a good level of knowledge (Arscott et al., 2000; Barat et al., 2001).
The following items were also assessed to ascertain whether the patient was involved in decision-making regarding their medication:

list-item.p: whether the patient had agreed to take the medication;
whether the medication had ever been changed without the patient’s permission;
whether anyone else helped the patient to make decisions about their medication.

sec.p: Finally, the questionnaire included some questions for the support workers themselves. We asked support workers whether the patient had the capacity to consent for medical treatment and whether there was a record of a formal assessment of capacity preceding the use of current medication present in the home. Data were analyzed using the SPSS statistical package (SPSS for Windows 16.0; SPSS Inc.; Chicago, Illinois, USA).

The audit was registered with the Greater Manchester West Mental Health NHS Foundation Trust Audit Department. We deemed this to be an audit because the question we were asking was: are health professionals complying with accepted standards of care concerning helping patients with intellectual disabilities to consent to medical treatment? The audit department gave us permission to proceed. Since patients with intellectual disabilities are a vulnerable population, we took a number of steps to safeguard the participants. First, we made clear in the covering letter that the patient was not required to take part in the audit, and if the patient or support worker had any queries then they could contact us by telephone for further information. If the patient did take part, then information was given to them in simple language that they could understand. Second, appropriate measures were taken to ensure confidentiality of patient data; all results from the questionnaire were recorded anonymously in an SPSS database and were password protected. Paper copies of questionnaires were stored in locked filing cabinets in secure offices at Greater Manchester West Mental Health NHS Foundation Trust. Third, it was made clear that the patients or their carers could withdraw their consent at any time.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 51 patients (72.9% of the sample) completed the questionnaires. Of these patients, six were not taking regular medications. The following results apply to the remaining 45 patients.

A total of 20 male and 25 female patients took part in the audit. The mean age of these patients was 51.5 years. Of these patients, 22 (48.9%) lived in supported tenancies, while 23 (51.1%) lived in privately funded care homes. On average, these patients were taking approximately five medications each.

sec.title: Medication knowledge
sec.p: Overall, medication knowledge was poor, with patients scoring less than 50% in all but one of the areas assessed (Figure 1). In particular, these patients showed a lack of knowledge about the proposed duration of their treatment, possible disadvantages and names of their medications, knowing these items in less than 15% of medications, on average.

caption.p: Average knowledge levels of medication in the sample. The knowledge level was calculated as a ratio of number of correct answers to number of medications the patient was taking. Patients had least knowledge of the duration of treatment, possible disadvantages and names of the medication, with patients knowing these items in an average of 13.84%, 9.93% and 4.27% of their medications, respectively.

sec.p: A total of eight patients (17.8%) were identified by staff as possessing mental capacity. On average, these patients showed good knowledge of the purpose of their medication, dose schedule, advantages of the treatment, consequences of not taking the medication and contraindicated foods and drinks. However, these patients showed poor knowledge of the proposed duration of their treatment and the possible disadvantages and names of their medications (Figure 2).

caption.p: Average knowledge levels of medication in intellectually disabled patients with capacity. Knowledge of contraindications, dose schedule, purpose of the medication and consequences of not taking the medication was good (above the 50% cut off). However, knowledge of the duration, possible disadvantages and the names of medications were poor.

sec.p: Overall, 37 patients (82.2%) were identified by staff as lacking the capacity to make decisions about their healthcare. These patients had less knowledge of their medications than the patients with capacity to make decisions, with an average of less than 50% scored in all assessed areas. As with the patients with capacity to make decisions, knowledge about the names of medications, the duration of treatment and possible disadvantages of the medication were particularly poor with an average of less than 10% scored in these areas (Figure 3).

caption.p: Average knowledge levels of medication in intellectually disabled patients without capacity. The knowledge level was calculated as a ratio of number of correct answers to number of medications the patient was taking. Knowledge was poor in all the areas (below the 50% cut off). Knowledge was particularly poor about the names, duration and possible disadvantages of the medication.

sec.title: Involvement in discussions about medications
sec.p: Our findings regarding the involvement of patients in discussions about their medications are summarized in Tables 1 and 2. All eight of the patients with capacity to make decisions said they agreed to take their medications. In addition, all these patients took their medications unaided. Two patients said that their medication had been altered without their permission, while the other six patients said this had never happened.

sec.p: Of the 37 patients without capacity to make decisions, 19 patients were either not involved with discussions about their medications or were unsure as to who helped them to make decisions about their medications and healthcare. Nine patients identified their doctor as the person who helped them to make decisions about their medications, while another nine patients identified their care staff or relatives as the people who helped them.

A record of a formal assessment of capacity, preceding the use of current medication, was present in only four of the patients’ homes. However, since we do not have access to each patient’s clinical notes, it is unclear whether such a capacity assessment was recorded elsewhere.

sec.title: Medication knowledge
sec.p: Overall, intellectually disabled patients’ knowledge of their medications is poor. However, this finding may not be a representative of intellectually disabled patients as a whole, due to the number of profoundly disabled patients present in this audit, who lacked the capacity to make healthcare decisions. Knowledge among patients with capacity to make decisions may be better (Arscott et al., 2000). Nevertheless, knowledge about possible adverse effects, the duration of treatment and the names of medications was very poor in all the patients. Interestingly, knowledge of possible adverse effects is also poor in the mainstream population (Ascione et al., 1986; Barat et al., 2001; Jaye et al., 2002; Kerzman et al., 2005; Modig et al., 2009). This suggests that all health professionals caring for all patients need to give more information about possible adverse effects.

Previous publications have shown that doctors do not always give patients information about the mechanism of action or possible adverse effects of medications (Storm et al., 2009; Wynne and Long, 1996; Ziegler et al., 2001). Although comparable studies do not appear to have been carried out in the intellectually disabled population, it is possible that the information provided by doctors to these patients follows a similar pattern. Strydom et al. (2002) found that patients with intellectual disabilities wanted to know more information specifically about the indications for their medication, possible side effects and contraindications. This suggests that health professionals are giving both mainstream patients and patients with learning disabilities similar information about their medications.

Despite this, a large number of patients identified their doctors as a source of information about medications, which suggests that health professionals are attempting to provide information to these patients. Therefore, to improve patient knowledge of their medications, it is important to ascertain exactly what information health professionals are attempting to give patients. If health professionals are attempting to convey all the information that is required by current best practice guidelines, then the delivery of this information needs to be improved.

There are many methods of communication that health professionals could be trained in to improve patient understanding of their medications. These include breaking information down into ‘chunks’ and using visual aids (Wong et al., 2000). Health professionals should also be aware of the methods they can use to overcome communication barriers, such as nonverbal demonstrations of medical procedures (Wong et al., 2000). In addition, leaflets about medications designed specifically for comprehension by intellectually disabled patients could be very useful. These may help understanding by allowing patients to learn about their medications in their own time, as well as reinforcing information that has been given during a consultation (Strydom et al., 2002; Kerzman et al., 2005).

sec.title: Capacity
sec.p: Many patients in this audit were found to lack the capacity to make decisions about their health. However, a record of a capacity assessment preceding the use of current medications was present in only four patients’ homes. Although this is not currently considered best practice, perhaps it would be beneficial to include these notes in the patient’s care plan at their home. This might help care staff to better understand the limits of the patient’s capacity, helping to prevent inappropriate deprivation of the liberty of the patient through the incorrect assumption that a patient is unable to take part in discussions about their medications (Age Concern, 2009).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Medication knowledge among patients with intellectual disabilities is poor. Knowledge of possible adverse effects, the duration of treatment and the names of medications is particularly inadequate. To improve knowledge, all patients with intellectual disabilities should be given the chance to discuss their medications with their doctor or other health professional. In addition, health professionals should be trained in communication skills that aid intellectually disabled patients' understanding of their medications.
